SENT.plain: A wide variety of dermatologic manifestations has been described in the antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
The most frequent skin lesion is livedo reticularis, present not only on the limbs but also on the trunk, with a fine irregular pattern
It belongs to the arterial subset of APS
Circumscribed ulcerations, resembling livedoid vasculitis, may be the first manifestation of APS
Ulcerations may also occur as a late complication of recurrent venous thrombosis
Extensive skin necrosis is a classic manifestation of catastrophic APS
Pseudo-vasculitis lesions are misdiagnosed if a skin biopsy is not performed, especially in the context of systemic lupus erythematosus
In systemic lupus erythematosus, primary anetoderma is always associated with antiphospholipid antibodies
